segment.source: Password must meet complexity requirements (Windows 10)
segment.target: Password must meet complexity requirements (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Password must meet complexity requirements security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Password must meet complexity requirements security policy setting.

segment.source: Password must meet complexity requirements
segment.target: Password must meet complexity requirements

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Password must meet complexity requirements security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Password must meet complexity requirements security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: The Passwords must meet complexity requirements policy setting determines whether passwords must meet a series of guidelines that are considered important for a strong password.
segment.target: The Passwords must meet complexity requirements policy setting determines whether passwords must meet a series of guidelines that are considered important for a strong password.

segment.source: Enabling this policy setting requires passwords to meet the following requirements:
segment.target: Enabling this policy setting requires passwords to meet the following requirements:

segment.source: Passwords may not contain the user's samAccountName (Account Name) value or entire displayName (Full Name value).
segment.target: Passwords may not contain the user's samAccountName (Account Name) value or entire displayName (Full Name value).

segment.source: Both checks are not case sensitive.
segment.target: Both checks are not case sensitive.

segment.source: The samAccountName is checked in its entirety only to determine whether it is part of the password.
segment.target: The samAccountName is checked in its entirety only to determine whether it is part of the password.

segment.source: If the samAccountName is less than three characters long, this check is skipped.
segment.target: If the samAccountName is less than three characters long, this check is skipped.

segment.source: The displayName is parsed for delimiters: commas, periods, dashes or hyphens, underscores, spaces, pound signs, and tabs.
segment.target: The displayName is parsed for delimiters: commas, periods, dashes or hyphens, underscores, spaces, pound signs, and tabs.

segment.source: If any of these delimiters are found, the displayName is split and all parsed sections (tokens) are confirmed to not be included in the password.
segment.target: If any of these delimiters are found, the displayName is split and all parsed sections (tokens) are confirmed to not be included in the password.

segment.source: Tokens that are less than three characters are ignored, and substrings of the tokens are not checked.
segment.target: Tokens that are less than three characters are ignored, and substrings of the tokens are not checked.

segment.source: For example, the name "Erin M. Hagens" is split into three tokens: "Erin", "M", and "Hagens".
segment.target: For example, the name "Erin M. Hagens" is split into three tokens: "Erin", "M", and "Hagens".

segment.source: Because the second token is only one character long, it is ignored.
segment.target: Because the second token is only one character long, it is ignored.

segment.source: Therefore, this user could not have a password that included either "erin" or "hagens" as a substring anywhere in the password.
segment.target: Therefore, this user could not have a password that included either "erin" or "hagens" as a substring anywhere in the password.

segment.source: The password contains characters from three of the following categories:
segment.target: The password contains characters from three of the following categories:

segment.source: Uppercase letters of European languages (A through Z, with diacritic marks, Greek and Cyrillic characters)
segment.target: Uppercase letters of European languages (A through Z, with diacritic marks, Greek and Cyrillic characters)

segment.source: Lowercase letters of European languages (a through z, sharp-s, with diacritic marks, Greek and Cyrillic characters)
segment.target: Lowercase letters of European languages (a through z, sharp-s, with diacritic marks, Greek and Cyrillic characters)

segment.source: Base 10 digits (0 through 9)
segment.target: Base 10 digits (0 through 9)

segment.source: Non-alphanumeric characters (special characters) (for example, !, $, , %)
segment.target: Non-alphanumeric characters (special characters) (for example, !, $, , %)

segment.source: Any Unicode character that is categorized as an alphabetic character but is not uppercase or lowercase.
segment.target: Any Unicode character that is categorized as an alphabetic character but is not uppercase or lowercase.

segment.source: This includes Unicode characters from Asian languages.
segment.target: This includes Unicode characters from Asian languages.

segment.source: Complexity requirements are enforced when passwords are changed or created.
segment.target: Complexity requirements are enforced when passwords are changed or created.

segment.source: The rules that are included in the Windows Server password complexity requirements are part of Passfilt.dll, and they cannot be directly modified.
segment.target: The rules that are included in the Windows Server password complexity requirements are part of Passfilt.dll, and they cannot be directly modified.

segment.source: Enabling the default Passfilt.dll may cause some additional Help Desk calls for locked-out accounts because users might not be used to having passwords that contain characters other than those found in the alphabet.
segment.target: Enabling the default Passfilt.dll may cause some additional Help Desk calls for locked-out accounts because users might not be used to having passwords that contain characters other than those found in the alphabet.

segment.source: However, this policy setting is liberal enough that all users should be able to abide by the requirements with a minor learning curve.
segment.target: However, this policy setting is liberal enough that all users should be able to abide by the requirements with a minor learning curve.

segment.source: Additional settings that can be included in a custom Passfilt.dll are the use of non–upper-row characters.
segment.target: Additional settings that can be included in a custom Passfilt.dll are the use of non–upper-row characters.

segment.source: Upper-row characters are those that are typed by holding down the SHIFT key and typing any of the digits from 1 through 10.
segment.target: Upper-row characters are those that are typed by holding down the SHIFT key and typing any of the digits from 1 through 10.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Not defined
segment.target: Not defined

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: Set Passwords must meet complexity requirements to Enabled.
segment.target: Set Passwords must meet complexity requirements to Enabled.

segment.source: This policy setting, combined with a minimum password length of 8, ensures that there are at least 218,340,105,584,896 different possibilities for a single password.
segment.target: This policy setting, combined with a minimum password length of 8, ensures that there are at least 218,340,105,584,896 different possibilities for a single password.

segment.source: This makes a brute force attack difficult, but still not impossible.
segment.target: This makes a brute force attack difficult, but still not impossible.

segment.source: The use of ALT key character combinations can greatly enhance the complexity of a password.
segment.target: The use of ALT key character combinations can greatly enhance the complexity of a password.

segment.source: However, requiring all users in an organization to adhere to such stringent password requirements can result in unhappy users and an extremely busy Help Desk.
segment.target: However, requiring all users in an organization to adhere to such stringent password requirements can result in unhappy users and an extremely busy Help Desk.

segment.source: Consider implementing a requirement in your organization to use ALT characters in the range from 0128 through 0159 as part of all administrator passwords.
segment.target: Consider implementing a requirement in your organization to use ALT characters in the range from 0128 through 0159 as part of all administrator passwords.

segment.source: (ALT characters outside of this range can represent standard alphanumeric characters that do not add additional complexity to the password.)
segment.target: (ALT characters outside of this range can represent standard alphanumeric characters that do not add additional complexity to the password.)

segment.source: Passwords that contain only alphanumeric characters are easy to compromise by using publicly available tools.
segment.target: Passwords that contain only alphanumeric characters are easy to compromise by using publicly available tools.

segment.source: To prevent this, passwords should contain additional characters and meet complexity requirements.
segment.target: To prevent this, passwords should contain additional characters and meet complexity requirements.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsAccount PoliciesPassword Policy
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsAccount PoliciesPassword Policy

segment.source: Default values
segment.target: Default values

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: Server type or Group Policy Object (GPO)
segment.target: Server type or Group Policy Object (GPO)

segment.source: Default value
segment.target: Default value

segment.source: Default domain policy
segment.target: Default domain policy

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Default domain controller policy
segment.target: Default domain controller policy

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Stand-alone server default settings
segment.target: Stand-alone server default settings

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Domain controller effective default settings
segment.target: Domain controller effective default settings

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Member server effective default settings
segment.target: Member server effective default settings

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Effective GPO default settings on client computers
segment.target: Effective GPO default settings on client computers

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Passwords that contain only alphanumeric characters are extremely easy to discover with several publicly available tools.
segment.target: Passwords that contain only alphanumeric characters are extremely easy to discover with several publicly available tools.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Configure the Passwords must meet complexity requirements policy setting to Enabled and advise users to use a variety of characters in their passwords.
segment.target: Configure the Passwords must meet complexity requirements policy setting to Enabled and advise users to use a variety of characters in their passwords.

segment.source: When combined with a Minimum password length of 8, this policy setting ensures that the number of different possibilities for a single password is so great that it is difficult (but not impossible) for a brute force attack to succeed.
segment.target: When combined with a Minimum password length of 8, this policy setting ensures that the number of different possibilities for a single password is so great that it is difficult (but not impossible) for a brute force attack to succeed.

segment.source: (If the Minimum password length policy setting is increased, the average amount of time necessary for a successful attack also increases.)
segment.target: (If the Minimum password length policy setting is increased, the average amount of time necessary for a successful attack also increases.)

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: If the default password complexity configuration is retained, additional Help Desk calls for locked-out accounts could occur because users might not be accustomed to passwords that contain non-alphabetical characters, or they might have problems entering passwords that contain accented characters or symbols on keyboards with different layouts.
segment.target: If the default password complexity configuration is retained, additional Help Desk calls for locked-out accounts could occur because users might not be accustomed to passwords that contain non-alphabetical characters, or they might have problems entering passwords that contain accented characters or symbols on keyboards with different layouts.

segment.source: However, all users should be able to comply with the complexity requirement with minimal difficulty.
segment.target: However, all users should be able to comply with the complexity requirement with minimal difficulty.

segment.source: If your organization has more stringent security requirements, you can create a custom version of the Passfilt.dll file that allows the use of arbitrarily complex password strength rules.
segment.target: If your organization has more stringent security requirements, you can create a custom version of the Passfilt.dll file that allows the use of arbitrarily complex password strength rules.

segment.source: For example, a custom password filter might require the use of non-upper-row symbols.
segment.target: For example, a custom password filter might require the use of non-upper-row symbols.

segment.source: (Upper-row symbols are those that require you to press and hold the SHIFT key and then press any of the digits between 1 and 0.) A custom password filter might also perform a dictionary check to verify that the proposed password does not contain common dictionary words or fragments.
segment.target: (Upper-row symbols are those that require you to press and hold the SHIFT key and then press any of the digits between 1 and 0.) A custom password filter might also perform a dictionary check to verify that the proposed password does not contain common dictionary words or fragments.

segment.source: The use of ALT key character combinations can greatly enhance the complexity of a password.
segment.target: The use of ALT key character combinations can greatly enhance the complexity of a password.

segment.source: However, such stringent password requirements can result in additional Help Desk requests.
segment.target: However, such stringent password requirements can result in additional Help Desk requests.

segment.source: Alternatively, your organization could consider a requirement for all administrator passwords to use ALT characters in the 0128–0159 range.
segment.target: Alternatively, your organization could consider a requirement for all administrator passwords to use ALT characters in the 0128–0159 range.

segment.source: (ALT characters outside of this range can represent standard alphanumeric characters that would not add additional complexity to the password.)
segment.target: (ALT characters outside of this range can represent standard alphanumeric characters that would not add additional complexity to the password.)

segment.target: Related topics
